Package moulton.scalable.containers

Class MenuManager

java.lang.Object
moulton.scalable.containers.MenuManager
public abstract class MenuManager
extends java.lang.Object
The menu manager will handle the rendering of its menu on a graphics object through render(Graphics). When the Container knows that it is time to render, have it call render(Graphics). Subclass this Menu Manager to create menu set-ups for yourself. Specifically, use createMenu() to create a menu Panel and add components to it. Make sure to save the panel you create to menu.

Will handle events for mouse moving (mouseMoved(int, int)), mouse pressing (mousePressed(int, int) and mouseReleased(int, int)), and key typing (keyTyped(char) and keyPressed(int)) as long as these event methods are being called, likely by Container.

Author:
Matthew Moulton

  • Field Details

    • menu

      protected Panel menu
      The panel that will serve as the menu. Exact usage is specified in the class documentation: Panel.
      See Also:
      hasMenu(), getMenu()

    • popup

      protected Popup popup
      A popup that should be drawn on top of the menu. If the popup is set (default is null), it will take precedence over the menu and take the action events such as mousePressed and mouseScrolled(int, int, int).
      See Also:
      getPopup(), setPopup(Popup)

    • cont

      protected Container cont
      The container for the menus to manage.

    • clicked

      protected Clickable clicked
      The Clickable that was last clicked. Clickables are only considered activated once the user has both clicked and released on the same object.
      See Also:
      getClicked(), setClicked(Clickable, int, int)

    • mouseX

      protected double mouseX
      mouseX and mouseY are the coordinates of the mouse when a mouse button is first pressed. Later updated by draggable components through mouseMoved(int, int) and DraggableComponent.drag(double, double) to be the location of the mouse at the point of last update.

    • mouseY

      protected double mouseY
      mouseX and mouseY are the coordinates of the mouse when a mouse button is first pressed. Later updated by draggable components through mouseMoved(int, int) and DraggableComponent.drag(double, double) to be the location of the mouse at the point of last update.

    • mousePressed

      protected boolean mousePressed
      Whether the mouse is currently pressed. Where the mouse was pressed is defined as (mouseX, mouseY).
      See Also:
      mousePressed(int, int), mouseReleased(int, int)

    • touchCheckList

      protected java.util.LinkedList<TouchResponsiveComponent> touchCheckList
      All of the components that the menu needs to check if touched every time the mouse moves
      See Also:
      addTouchResponsiveComponent(TouchResponsiveComponent), removeTouchResponsiveComponent(TouchResponsiveComponent)

    • FORM_END

      public static final Clickable FORM_END
      A clickable that can be set to the next in a form chain if the next should just be a deselection.

  • Constructor Details

    • MenuManager

      public MenuManager​(Container cont)
      Saves the cont field as cont.
      Parameters:
      cont - the container for the menus to manage.

  • Method Details

    • createMenu

      public abstract void createMenu()
      Implement to define the properties of the menu to manage. The created menu should be held in menu, to be usable by other methods. Thus, all components on the menu should have menu saved as their parent Panel.

    • clickableAction

      public abstract void clickableAction​(Clickable c)
      Implement to add functionality to any clickable components in the menu managed. A good way to check for component identity is by using Clickable.getId().
      Parameters:
      c - the clickable that is being activated, the action will start

    • lostFocusAction

      public abstract void lostFocusAction​(Clickable c)
      Implement to add functionality to any clickable components in the menu managed once they lose focus. Focus is defined as going from clicked to not clicked. For buttons, this occurs once the mouse has been released. For text boxes, this occurs when something else is clicked. A good way to check for component identity is by using Clickable.getId().
      Parameters:
      c - the clickable that is being activated, the action will start

    • mousePressed

      public void mousePressed​(int x, int y)
      The Moulton Scalable Menus handles the mouse press once this method has been called by a mouse listener external to Moulton Scalable Menus. This method systematically processes every component in menu to see if the (x,y) coordinate of the mouse click, as determined by the mouse event, was within the boundaries of the component. If so, the menu remembers that component as clicked for the occurrence of a mouse release.
      Parameters:
      x - the x position of the mouse relative to the JFrame
      y - the y position of the mouse relative to the JFrame

    • mousePressed

      protected void mousePressed​(int x, int y, java.util.Collection<MenuComponent> collection)
      internal recursive mousePressed call
      Parameters:
      x - the x position of the mouse relative to the JFrame
      y - the y position of the mouse relative to the JFrame
      collection - the collection to iterate through

    • mouseReleased

      public void mouseReleased​(int x, int y)
      The Moulton Scalable Menus handles the mouse release once this method has been called by another source. This method checks to see whether the component that the user first clicked on is the same that they released on. Sets clicked as necessary.

      If the click was successful, it is determined whether the clickable has an associated click event by calling Clickable.getClickAction(). If not, or if the action does not consume the event, the manager then calls clickableAction(Clickable). and the mouse (x,y) coordinate as determined by the mouse event is still on that component.

      Parameters:
      x - the x coordinate of the mouse when released
      y - the y coordinate of the mouse when released

    • mouseScrolled

      public void mouseScrolled​(int mouseX, int mouseY, int scrollAmount)
      Call this when the mouse is scrolled. Positive values are down, and negative values are up. The scroll will be passed to the scroll bar of the relevant touched ScrollableComponent.
      Parameters:
      mouseX - the x-position of the mouse when the scrolling occurred
      mouseY - the y-position of the mouse when the scrolling occurred
      scrollAmount - the amount that the mouse is scrolled.

    • componentLostFocus

      public void componentLostFocus​(Clickable c)
      Called when the component lost focus and may need to report changes. If the component has a registered lost focus event Clickable.getLostFocusAction(), then that will be called. If not, or if the event remains unconsumed, lostFocusAction(Clickable) will be called.

      For components that lose focus on release (Clickable.isDeselectedOnRelease()), losing focus is defined as going from a clicked state to a non-clicked state. The losing focus event will occur regardless of whether the click was successful.

      For components that do not lose focus on release, the meaning is slightly different. The component will keep focus only if the click is successful (if not, it will lose focus and trigger this event just like deselectOnRelease was true), and if so, it will lose focus as soon as another component is first clicked (regardless of whether that click is successful).

      Parameters:
      c - the Clickable menu component that lost focus and needs to report changes to its menu

    • keyTyped

      public void keyTyped​(char key)
      Handles any key typed transactions. If the clicked is a TextInputComponent, the event is passed to it. This will not occur automatically when a key is typed, rather, it needs to be called externally.
      Parameters:
      key - the key that was pressed

    • keyPressed

      public void keyPressed​(int keyInt)
      Handles key pressed transactions for the menu. If the clicked is a TextBox, this method will check to see if the key press was either the left or right arrow keys. Those keys shift the index for the text box.
      Parameters:
      keyInt - the int code of the key pressed. This corresponds to KeyEvent.getExtendedKeyCode().

    • mouseMoved

      public void mouseMoved​(int x, int y)
      This will report to the selected Draggable how much the mouse has moved since the draggable was first clicked. When the draggable uses some of the change, it can update the mouse coordinates by returning an array of how much was used. (Index 0 for x, index 1 for y.)

      This method is also responsible for executing touch events and updating the cursor if necessary. If multiple touched components alter the cursor type, the most recently added to the touch list will take precedence.

      Parameters:
      x - the mouse x coordinate in pixels
      y - the mouse y coordinate in pixels

    • render

      public void render​(java.awt.Graphics g)
      Renders the menu that is being managed (menu).
      Parameters:
      g - the Graphics to render on

    • hasMenu

      public boolean hasMenu()
      Returns:
      true if menu is not null. Otherwise, returns false.

    • getMenu

      public Panel getMenu()
      Returns:
      the menu that is currently being used. Defined as menu.

    • getPopup

      public Popup getPopup()
      Gets the current popup for this menu. Only one popup can be active at a time.
      Returns:
      the current popup
      See Also:
      setPopup(Popup)

    • setPopup

      public void setPopup​(Popup pop)
      Sets the popup for this menu. Only one popup can be active at a time.
      Parameters:
      pop - the popup to be set for this menu manager.
      See Also:
      getPopup()

    • setClicked

      public void setClicked​(Clickable clicked, int x, int y)
      Sets clicked to defined. If clicked was non-null before the change, the clickable will be updated with its new non-clicked status, and any losing focus events will be triggered. The new clicked will be notified of this event.
      Parameters:
      clicked - the component that has been clicked. Saved as clicked
      x - the x-location of the mouse when clicked. Measured in pixels.
      y - the y-location of the mouse when clicked. Measured in pixels.

    • getClicked

      public Clickable getClicked()
      Returns the currently selected clickable component.
      Returns:
      clicked

    • addTouchResponsiveComponent

      public void addTouchResponsiveComponent​(TouchResponsiveComponent comp)
      Adds the component to the list of components to check each time the mouse moves. If the component is later removed from visibility (for example if the panel it is on is removed from the root-tree), then the programmer needs to call removeTouchResponsiveComponent(TouchResponsiveComponent).
      Parameters:
      comp - the component to add on
      See Also:
      removeTouchResponsiveComponent(TouchResponsiveComponent)

    • removeTouchResponsiveComponent

      public void removeTouchResponsiveComponent​(TouchResponsiveComponent comp)
      Removes the specified component from the touch component list.
      Parameters:
      comp - the component to remove
      See Also:
      addTouchResponsiveComponent(TouchResponsiveComponent)

    • findComponent

      public Clickable findComponent​(java.lang.String idToFind, Panel startPoint)
      Finds the clickable component with the specified ID. It is assumed that there will only be one since ID codes are intended to be unique. Uses the recursive method findComponent(String, Panel, Panel).
      Parameters:
      idToFind - the ID that should be matched in the found component
      startPoint - the panel where the searching should begin (for speed reasons). If no panel is specified, the menu root panel (menu will be used as the starting point.
      Returns:
      the component found that has the matching ID, or if such component cannot be found, null.

    • findComponent

      protected Clickable findComponent​(java.lang.String idToFind, Panel startPoint, Panel ignore)
      The recursive method to find the component with the specified ID. Use findComponent(String, Panel) for full functionality. This is just meant to be the recursive version.
      Parameters:
      idToFind - the ID that should be matched in the found component
      startPoint - the panel where the searching should begin (for speed reasons). If no panel is specified, the menu root panel (menu will be used as the starting point.
      ignore - this panel and its children components will not be searched. The reason for this is because they have already been searched earlier, so they aren't searched again. If no panel is given, then this method will not move up the panel tree, or in other words, the parent panels and their components will not be searched, only the subdirectories of the specified start point panel.
      Returns:
      the component found that has the matching ID, or if such component cannot be found, null.
